query: What is the most cost-effective way to provide dietary enrichment for captive primates?
relevant_summary: No evidence was found regarding the cost-effectiveness of primate dietary enrichment. One replicated, controlled study in the USA reported that an enrichment task took less time to complete when monkeys were in social groups than when feeding alone (1343). One before-and-after study in Italy found that in the presence of their groupmates monkeys ate more unfamiliar foods during the first encounter (1343). Two before-and-after studies in Japan and the USA found that when the number of feeds per day were increased the amount of time spent feeding increased in chimpanzees, but hair eating also increased in baboons (1337).

Two before-and-after studies in Japan and the USA found that when the number of feeds per day were increased the amount of time spent feeding increased in chimpanzees, but hair eating also increased in baboons (1337).","query":"What is the most cost-effective way to provide dietary enrichment for captive primates?"}

query: What is the most cost-effective way to provide dietary enrichment for captive primates?
relevant_summary: One replicated, controlled study in the USA reported that an enrichment task took less time to complete when monkeys were in social groups than when feeding alone [1343]. One before-and-after study in Italy found that in the presence of their groupmates monkeys ate more unfamiliar foods during the first encounter [1343]. One replicated, before-and-after study in the Netherlands and Germany found that when presented with stinging nettles captive gorillas used the same processing skills as wild gorillas to forage [1332]. No evidence was captured for the effects of providing nectar (including artificial nectar) to primates [1331].

tools_called.args: {"action_ids":["1343","1332","1331"],"query":"What is the most cost-effective way to provide dietary enrichment for captive primates?","summary":"One replicated, controlled study in the USA reported that an enrichment task took less time to complete when monkeys were in social groups than when feeding alone [1343]. One before-and-after study in Italy found that in the presence of their groupmates monkeys ate more unfamiliar foods during the first encounter [1343]. One replicated, before-and-after study in the Netherlands and Germany found that when presented with stinging nettles captive gorillas used the same processing skills as wild gorillas to forage [1332]. No evidence was captured for the effects of providing nectar (including artificial nectar) to primates [1331]."}

query: Which is a more effective breeding stimulus for amphibians: simulating rainfall with sound recordings or allowing them to hibernate?
relevant_summary: There is no evidence to support the effectiveness of simulating rainfall with sound recordings or allowing temperate amphibians to hibernate as a breeding stimulus (1867, 1868).

query: What is the recommended protocol for managing the dental health of captive carnivores?
relevant_summary: No actions were found that directly address a recommended protocol for managing the dental health of captive carnivores.
